posts.cooked:
I want to couple 2 DC motors with encoders to my shooter mechanism that is capable of shooting balls with speed control.

My past experience without any feedback loop, the motors are not consistent all the time and it takes time to build up speed again for next ball shot.

I tried to obtain the rpm (not accurate reading) and pass it to PID control to maintain at the setpoint rpm but failed. I’m sure my PID control functions are working properly as I tested implementing position control and worked flawlessly.

I would love to know how the implementation of speed control can be done using a proper velocity formula paired with PID control.

Thanks in advance for any help

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
Seeing your code would be of great value to help answer your question.

ninja29:

I tried to obtain the rpm (not accurate reading) and pass it to PID control to maintain at the setpoint rpm but failed.

This needs to be explained in much greater detail to understand what you did and what went wrong.

posts.name: Kevin Rowney
posts.cooked:
I’m not sure if I have a constructive solution to this problem, but am still curious about your approach since I’m interested in doing something similar.

Are you addressing the motors via the CAM bus that in turn will read encoders, or is there some other way you are controlling them?

Was thinking of using that approach via the CAM bus with the SPARK MAX controller, but its a bit spendy.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
Is this using FRC hardware/software (i.e. RoboRIO and WPILib)? What motor, motor controller, and encoder are you using, and how is the encoder wired? What language are you using?

What do you mean the RPM reading is inaccurate.

Code link would be helpful, as mentioned above.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
ninja29:

I would love to know how the implementation of speed control can be done using a proper velocity formula paired with PID control.

If you haven’t yet, check out the tuning demo on the wpilib docs . It includes explanation of the feed-forward and feed-back portions of the system you describe.

Note the code is left as an exercise to the user. But the demos should show you what the end product should look and act like.

link_counts.title: Tuning a Flywheel Velocity Controller — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.cooked:
I have attached my code for timer interrupt and PID control. I am using STM32F401 as my main processing unit. So basically every 10ms, timer 5 will trigger a callbackfunction to carry out the velocity calculation and pass it to PID control.

my motor specifications: Rated speed: 230rpm Encoder PPR : 500 Gear ratio: 1:27

I am not using any FRC related software, currently I am using a STM32 to obtain the encoder readings and perform processing.

To clarify " RPM reading is inaccurate", my RPM reading obtained did not match with the rated motor RPM . As for my motor driver, I am using a generic single channel motor driver from cytron
Thanks for the resource, will definitely look into it and corporate it into my design

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked:
All of the code would have been better but I assume some things and make suggestions.

Assuming your motor speed is 162 under some load then that is reasonable for a no load speed of 230 and not a problem.

I’ll guess that the 0.00 speeds are you polling the encoder way too fast for it to respond with new correct values. Try a slower loop speed like 2000ms to give it a few data points with which to calculate the velocity and see if that helps.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked:
There’s a few potential issues I see with the code on a first glance.

If PPR and encoder_pulses are both defined as ints, you may be doing integer division instead of the intended floating point division. Likewise if motor_velocity_rpm and GEAR_RATIO are defined as integers.

It’s unclear to me why you are dividing by 1000 here motor_velocity_rpm = (motor_velocity_rpm * GEAR_RATIO)/1000; Also, if you’re gearing down, make sure you’re dividing by 27 to get the RPM of the mechanism rather than multiplying.

errorTotal will never change if it starts at zero or if the error ever exceeds the integralActiveZone.

I don’t know if I would set the derivative term to zero if the position term is 0. Seems unnecessary.

Altogether, I think you need to insert more print statements to see where your bug is. Print out current_encoder_pulses every time step, and print out some intermediate calculations.

Edit:

In fact, I’m almost certain that the first two points are the problem. 162 = 6000 * 27 / 1000. So, the first line is returning either 0 or 6000 due to the type problem, and then the second line is converting that to 162 instead of 6000 / 27 = 222 (i.e. the rated RPM of your motor).
